Award.AwardTitle: Learning and Teaching Geometry: VideoCases for Mathematics Professional Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Learning and Teaching Geometry project (LTG) creates five video case modules for use in professional development of middle school mathematics teachers. The materials are designed to develop teachers' understanding of mathematics knowledge for teaching similarity. Module I, the foundation module, focuses on a thorough grounding of similarity and contains 6-8 video case sessions. The four extension modules offer options for further exploration: (1) Definitions and Theorems; (2) The Role of Language in Geometry; (3) Choosing and Using Technological Tools; and (4) Bridging to High School Geometry. In total, 18-24 video cases are produced, which, taken together, form the curriculum of a 45 to 60-hour professional development course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the Learning and Teaching Geometry (LTG) project was to produce a set of materials that enables teachers to expand their mathematical knowledge for teaching in the domain of geometric similarity. In accordance with this goal, the project has generated materials to support 54 hours of professional development that prepare teachers to meet the challenges of teaching similarity in accordance with the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics. In addition to targeting more than 20 content standards, the materials highlight recommended mathematical practices such as making use of geometric structure, attending to precision, constructing viable arguments and critiquing the reasoning of others, and selecting and using appropriate tools in the context of teaching similarity.

 

The LTG materials engage teachers in learning about similarity through a series of video cases in which specific and increasingly complex mathematical concepts are presented within the dynamics of classroom practice. The materials are organized into five modules: a Foundation Module and four Extension Modules. Each module contains a sequence of video cases through which teachers explore the mathematics content by viewing, analyzing, and discussing video clips, comparing and contrasting issues across cases, and making links to their own instructional practice. The materials are “highly specified,” which means they contain extensive supports and resources for facilitators to ensure that they will be utilized with fidelity and meet specific learning goals.

 

All of the LTG materials were pilot tested by multiple facilitators over a five-year period. Based on those pilots, including feedback from the facilitators and teachers, the materials underwent multiple rounds of revision. The Foundation Module was piloted in eight sites across the United States. As part of the pilot tests, teachers took three pre-post assessments: a knowledge assessment and two assessments embedded within the PD. In addition, the teachers nominated colleagues who were not attending the sessions but who would be willing to take all of the assessments. Thus, in addition to 87 treatment teachers there were 39 comparison teachers.

 

Professional development based on the Foundation Module had a significant, positive impact on the treatment teachers. On the knowledge assessment, the treatment teachers demonstrated an average gain of almost 9 percentage points from pretest to posttest. By contrast, the comparison teachers demonstrated an average gain of less than 2 percentage points. Similarly, on the embedded assessments the treatment teachers showed greater knowledge gains relative to the comparison teachers. The treatment teachers significantly improved on 5 of the 6 embedded assessment questions, whereas the comparison teachers did not significantly improve on any question.

 

Two of the pilot sites agreed to administer an assessment to students of both the treatment teachers and the comparison teachers. In total, data were collected from 271 students (163 treatment students, 108 comparison students). Students whose teachers received professional development based on the Foundation Module showed significantly greater improvement on the assessment relative to students whose teachers did not receive the professional development. The average pretest–posttest gain for students of treatment group teachers was more than 6 percentage points higher than the gain for students of comparison group teachers.

 

The results from piloting the Foundation Module offer evidence of the promise of the LTG materials to achieve the intended teacher knowledge outcomes, including gains in geometry content knowledge along with the knowledge to effectively convey that information in the classroom.
